get over.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to become well again after an illness
get over.translation[0].definitions[0].e: It’s taken me ages to get over the flu.
get over.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to begin to feel better after a very upsetting experience
get over.translation[0].definitions[1].e: She never got over the death of her son.
get over.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to succeed in communicating ideas or information to other people
get over.translation[0].definitions[2].e: It’s important that we get this message over to young people.
get over.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to do and finish something difficult that you have to do
get over.translation[0].definitions[3].e: I’ll be in touch once I’ve got my exams over.
I can’t wait to get the interview over with.
get over.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to successfully deal with a problem or difficulty
get over.translation[0].definitions[4].e: I don’t know how we’re going to get over this problem.
Once we’ve got over the first few months, we should be making a reasonable profit.
get over.translation[0].definitions[5].d: used to say that you are very surprised, shocked, or amused by something
get over.translation[0].definitions[5].e: I can’t get over how well you look.
get over.translation[0].definitions[6].d: to stop being so sensitive or proud
get over.translation[0].definitions[6].e: Get over yourself! Nobody cares if you’ve made a mistake.
